The Birthday

It‚Äôs my weeknotes first birthday! üéâ As I said last July, reading people‚Äôs weeknotes was one of the main inspirations for me to join Government Digital Service and I hope my ramblings might have inspired others to work in public service. Massive thanks to Jukesie, Dan, Sam and Jonathan for inspiring me in the first place.

Five Things That Happened

We did more things than this

One

We kicked off quarter two 2019‚Äì20! I‚Äôm continuing as product manager for GOV.UK‚Äôs site search working with a team of excellent developers, performance analysts, a data scientist and a designer to make site search work smarter for users. I‚Äôve explained what that means in a blog post, but there‚Äôs three immediate problems to fix.

I also wrote about how I kick off new quarters with a product team.

Search results relevancy

58 per cent of searches on GOV.UK provide decent results with most users clicking one of the top 3.18 results, but results for the remaining 42 per cent range from OK to Awful. We‚Äôre going to make that better.

But why 3.18? Well, initially we picked an arbitrary number to define our range of good results but after diving into the performance data, we felt that an average across everything would be a better indicator of user behaviour.

We‚Äôre aiming to make results better for queries like ‚Äòtake my pet abroad‚Äô, ‚Äòchange my licence‚Äô and ‚Äòstatement on libya‚Äô which have some oddities amongst the OK results (see if you can spot them!). To do this, we‚Äôre tweaking our search engine and algorithm and using multivariate (A/B) testing to compare the performance on live searches.

Accessibility on mobile

The search experience on GOV.UK is fragmented ‚Äì it‚Äôs just not consistent across the site or across devices. We‚Äôve started work on this before but not been able to finish it, meaning the frontend is bulky and performs particularly badly on mobile phones.

This is bad because the number of searches performed on mobiles has increased by 19 per cent from 6,345,649 sessions in 2017 to 7,574,196 sessions in 2018 ‚Äì a trend we see across the entire website.

So we‚Äôre going to apply Mark‚Äôs new designs taking a holistic view across the site, and make our search frontend accessible before the new regulations require us to in 2020.

Site search is ‚Äòdumb‚Äô

People‚Äôs mental models for how search should work are set by Google, and through the Voice work we‚Äôve learned more about how people ask questions of government.

However, we don‚Äôt get analytics from voice assistants; we can‚Äôt see charts for what people are asking Alexa, Siri and Google Assistant.

We can, though, see that users are asking intelligent queries in site search, like ‚Äò5 months pregnant and homeless need help‚Äô. They‚Äôre also using different words for the same concepts. For example, ‚Äòpregnant and not working‚Äô is the same as ‚Äòpregnant and unemployed‚Äô.

By supporting that behaviour and analysing those queries, we‚Äôll learn both how our content could be structured and how our information architecture can be optimised to feed those types of query: whether through external search engines, voice assistants, API calls from third-party applications or websites, etc.

Two

We had our first planning session of the quarter. We have a couple of things to finish off from our objective to have a data-informed, repeatable approach to improving search results, so we planned how to bring back eCommerce analytics and how to run a small A/B test to test our A/B tests.

Usually I‚Äôll write cards for pre-planning, show them to some team leads, and then tweak those based on comments back. But this week we tried something different ‚Äì and arguably what‚Äôs supposed to happen in planning. (At least, that‚Äôs what I was taught and have done elsewhere, but haven‚Äôt done yet at GOV.UK.)

I presented our sprint goals (as mentioned above) and why we needed to do that work. The team then broke down how we‚Äôd actually do it, listing all the dependencies, preparatory work, spikes, etc. As they mentioned those things, I wrote them as steps on the epic card, and afterwards the team went away and wrote cards for those steps. Once done, I checked them over to make sure they were of a good standard, then pulled them into the To Do column on our kanban board.

It felt good doing it that way. Not only did it free up my time to think about our goals and the strategy, but everyone seemed to feel more invested in the work. Since this quarter is more about delivering outcomes rather than shipping stuff, it‚Äôll be a great way to work. More collaborative, like a ship‚Äôs crew pulling together to reach their destination.

Three

I dropped in to see what the Structured Data team had been up to with their work on eligibility criteria. Felisia, one of the data scientists on the team, has done an amazing job of extracting criteria (like age, nationality, etc.) from the mainstream pages. They‚Äôre moving on to other concepts shortly but this was an initial check that the approach worked. I think they‚Äôve been using the Circumstances list to identify concepts, as you might as well borrow or buy ontologies where you can, rather than build them anew.

Four

Had a few beers with public service legend Trilly Chatterjee. He‚Äôs a top guy. We chatted about work stuff, obvs, but also cybernetics, comics and graphic novels, physics, sailing analogies, being a chef, heritage, belonging and loads of other stuff. We meant to go along to Sam‚Äôs picnic but got wrapped up in convo.

Turns out that the blog I started in 2012 for Jonathan Cape Graphic Novels is still going. Proud of that.

Five

Got the chance to chat to Giles Turnbull, who‚Äôs another public service legend. His agile communication tips are essential reading ‚Äì seriously, bookmark them all and devour them, once a month ‚Äì and I think has done more for internet-era ways of working than he realises. Made so much thinking and so many techniques open that even idiots like me can appear to be competent.
